tree1.png.description: A portion of a decision tree (leading from utensil to knife) with two levels.

tree2.png.description: A portion of a decision tree (leading from utensil to knife, and from not-utensil to cup) with three levels.

tree3.png.description: A decision tree that categorizes knife, fork, spoon, plate, mug, and cup

tree-w-blanks.png.description: A decision tree (with blanks) that categorizes knife, fork, spoon, plate, mug, and cup

tree4.png.description: A less-accurate decision tree that categorizes knife, fork, spoon, plate, mug, and cup.

stump.png.description: A one-level decision tree showing three branches (teens, twenties and thirties), coming from the root node of age.

age-stump-checks.png.description: A one-level decision tree showing three branches (teens, twenties and thirties), coming from the root node of age with checkmarks indicating correct predictions

final-tree.png.description: A decision tree that predicts if individuals will buy a video game

history-stump.png.description: A decision tree stump for the column shopping history

interest-stump.png.description: A decision tree stump for the column interest in game

terminology-tree.png.description: A decision tree indicating where the root, nodes, and leaves are located

iris-data.png.description: An excerpt of Ronald Fisher's Iris dataset
iris-data.png.caption: British statistician and biologist Ronald Fisher first published his findings about the Iris Dataset in 1936. The dataset includes 150 different plants' sepal length, sepal width, petal length, and petal width. Today, this dataset is considered a go-to dataset useful for illustrating a wide range of problems in data science and machine learning.
